QUALITY
A few select Westerns were improved, whilst the others together with the Nuwara Eliyas and Uva/Uda Pussellawas showed no significant change. Low Growns were similar to last.
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Auction offerings totalled 4.98 M/Kgs. There was fair demand.
Ex-Estate offerings totalled 0.74 M/Kgs. Quality of teas from the Western slopes had a small selection of teas showing an element of improvement, whilst the others showed no change.
Better Western BOP/BOPF's - A selection of invoices appreciated by up to Rs. 50 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and at times easier by a similar margin. In the Below Best category, a few select coloury BOP's appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were firm and easier by a similar margin. Corresponding BOPF's followed a similar trend with a few select invoices appreciating by Rs. 20-30 per kg and the others barely selling around last week's levels. At the lower end, BOP's appreciated by Rs. 50-80 per kg, whilst the corresponding BOPF's were firm and up to Rs. 20 per kg dearer for select invoices. Nuwara Eliya BOP/BOPF's - A few select invoices sold around last week's levels, whilst the others remained unsold. Uda Pussellawa BOP's were Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the corresponding BOPF's were generally firm. Uva BOP's - A few select invoices were substantially dearer, whilst the others were firm and up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer. Poor leaf teas were lower by a similar margin. Corresponding BOPF's were barely steady.
High & Medium Grown CTC - BP1's had hardly any offerings. PF1's - Select Best were firm, whilst the others were irregular. Corresponding Low Grown varieties - BP1's continued to sell around last week's levels. PF1's - A few Select Best invoices were firm, whilst the others declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more for the poorer sorts.
Selective purchasing by shippers to the UK and South Africa. Shippers to Japan and China continued to be active perhaps less intensely, whilst shippers to the CIS continued to operate on a wider cross-section of the teas.
Low Growns comprised of 2.0 M/Kgs. All categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, Select Best and Best BOP1's were firm, whilst the Below Best together with the bolder varieties appreciated. The balance were firm. High-priced OP1's were firm, whilst the Best varieties appreciated. Below Best and poorer sorts too followed a similar trend. OP's/OPA's, in general, appreciated. Select Best and Best PEK's were easier, whilst the Below Best and clean leaf teas at the bottom sold around last levels. High-priced PEK1's maintained, whilst the balance together with the teas, where quality was not maintained, declined. Smaller varieties too followed a similar trend.
Select Best FBOP's were firm to selective dearer, whilst the Best and Below Best together with cleaner teas at the bottom appreciated. The balance sold around last levels.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy teas were firm to dearer, whilst the Best and Below Best appreciated. The balance were irregular following quality. Well-made FF1's were firm, whilst the Below Best and cleaner teas at the bottom appreciated. The balance were firm.
World Tea News
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 03RD/ 04TH DECEMBER 2024
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
A selection of better teas were firm and dearer, whilst the others were irregular. Better demand at the lower end as well, particularly for the coloury sorts
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's - A selection of invoices appreciated by up to Rs. 50 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular. In the Below Best category, a few select coloury invoices appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were often lower by a similar margin. Teas at the lower end of the market appreciated by Rs. 50-80 per kg. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer. Uva's - A few Select Best invoices were substantially dearer, whilst the others were firm and up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer. Poor leaf teas were lower by a similar margin.
BOPF
Best Western's - A selection of invoices gained by Rs. 50 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and easier by a similar margin. In the Below Best category, select coloury teas were Rs. 20-30 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. At the lower end, select coloury teas gained by up to Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others were barely steady. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were generally firm. Uva's were barely steady.
OP/OPA
OP/OPA's, in general, gained by Rs. 50-100 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
A limited selection of flavoury PEK's that were available, were firm to irregularly easier. Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm on last week levels, whilst the PEK1's were dearer.  Select Best Rotovane PEK's sold around last levels following quality/special inquiry, whilst the others were irregularly dearer.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Flavoury FBOP's were mostly unsold. Well-made Orthodox Leafy FBOP's were easier by Rs. 50 per kg and more at times, whilst the others together with FF1's, in general, were firm on last.

OFF GRADES
FGS1/FGS
Select invoices in the Best category were irregular. Clean leaf Below Best varieties which commenced firm gained by Rs. 30-50 per kg as the sale progressed following special inquiry. Teas at the bottom end of the market which commenced firm, appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more as the sale progressed. Low Growns - Clean leaf varieties were firm to selectively dearer, whilst the balance maintained. CTC's - Clean leaf sorts were firm, whilst the poorer varieties gained by Rs. 10-20 per kg.
BROKENS
Best varieties were firm to selectively dearer following quality. Below Best sorts which were dearer by Rs. 10-20 per kg at the commencement of the sale, gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more as the sale progressed. Poorer varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 10-20 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category which commenced firm, appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more towards the latter part of the sale. The balance maintained. Below Best varieties which commenced Rs. 10-20 per kg dearer, gained further as the sale progressed. Select invoices in the poorer category were dearer by Rs. 10-20 per kg, whilst the balance were firm.

Select Best Dust1's were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the Best varieties were firm to dearer  by Rs. 20 per kg. Below Best varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts were marginally dearer by Rs. 20 per kg. Low Grown - Best invoices were firm, whilst the Below Best varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 30-40 per kg. The poorer sorts appreciated by Rs. 20 per kg.
Best High and Mid Grown CTC's appreciated by Rs. 30-50 per kg, whilst the Below Best varieties together with the poorer sorts were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Best Low Grown varieties were firm, whilst the Below Best and poorer sorts were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg.
DUST
Clean leaf secondaries appreciated by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts decreased by Rs. 20 per kg. Best Low Growns were firm, whilst the poorer sorts were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-30 per kg.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 2ND/ 03RD DECEMBER 2024 (SALE NO.49)
Good general demand prevailed in the market for the 165,180 packages (11,206,558.00 kilos) available; 26.72% remained unsold.
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers maintained activity but at lower levels with Afghanistan and Bazaar active. Yemen and other Middle Eastern countries showed more enquiry while Egyptian Packers lent strong support. Kazakhstan, other CIS states were less active while there was improved absorption from UK. Russia operated at lower levels while Sudan showed more interest. South Sudan maintained some activity with China more selective. Local Packers were active while Somalia maintained good support at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades    -   83,600 packages (5,543,740.00 kilos) - 27.70% unsold.
Dust Grades     -         59,800 packages (4,471,448.00 kilos) - 29.10% unsold.
Secondary Grades   -         21,780 packages (1,200,370.00 kilos) - 16.43% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3) BP1:
Best
- Irregular and ranged between USC8 above last rates for a few invoices to easier by up to USC32 with most offers remaining unsold.
Brighter
- Mostly easier and lost up to USC20 but select lines were up to USC3 dearer with some teas advancing by USC90.
Mediums
- KTDA mediums saw irregular enquiry varying between USC5 dearer and select Invoices gained USC43 to easier by up to USC13 with plantation mediums steady to USC22 above previous levels.
Lower Medium
- Were well competed for irregularly advancing by up to USC30 with select teas discounted by up to USC6.
Plainer
- Met strong enquiry at firm to mostly dearer by up to USC8.
PF1:
Best
- Saw irregular demand and ranged between USC10 above last levels to mostly easier by up to USC15.
Brighter
- Shed up to USC19.
Mediums
- KTDA mediums were irregular and varied between firm to USC14 dearer with some lines USC32 above previous rates to easier by up to USC35. Plantation mediums lost up to USC17 but a few lines were USC10 dearer.
Lower Medium
- Irregular and varied between steady to USC17 dearer to easier by up to USC31.
Plainer
- Some lines were up to USC11 above last levels to easier by up to USC5 with others USC24 below previous rates.

BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 2ND NOVEMBER 2024 (Sale No.30)
CTC LEAF
: 60,737 packages of tea on offer met with a good demand.
BROKENS
: Good liquoring Brokens were a good market and were about steady whilst their Medium varieties eased slightly in line with quality. Plainer types were easier with more withdrawals. BLF teas met with less demand and witnessed heavy withdrawals.
FANNINGS
: Good liquoring Fannings were a good market and sold around last levels easing slightly. Medium types were easier whilst the plainest eased further with more withdrawals. BLF teas met with less demand and witnessed heavy withdrawals.
DUST:
9,885 packages of tea on offer met very good demand. Good liquoring Dusts sold well at around last
levels. Their Mediums were fully firm to slightly dearer by Tk.3/- to Tk.5/- closely following quality. Plain and BLF Dusts met with a little more interest and had less withdrawals compared to last. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS:
There was a little less competition this week resulting in more withdrawals particularly for the plainer types. Blenders continued to be active whilst Loose tea buyers were operating in lesser strength this week.
Dusts were a dearer market.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 30) Avg : Tk 218.61, Sold 70.52% , (Sale 29) Avg : Tk 216.55, Sold 78.56%

There was less and selective interest for the 2840 packages on offer.

KOLKATA SALE  CTC MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to fair demand. Assams seen so far tending easier and seeing some
withdrawals. Fannings meeting with better demand. Plainer Dooars selling around last levels.
BUYING PATTERN:
Western India - Selective on the better teas
TCPL - Good support
Hindistan Tea exports - Operating
Exporters : Some enquiry on bolder brokens and fannings
KOLKATA SALE  ORTHODOX MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Few tippy teas on offer sold readily. Well made whole
leaf and larger brokens irregular around last. Smaller brokens tending irregularly lower.
Remainder whole leaf and brokens irregular and at times tending lower following quality.
Leafy fannings and cleaner secondaries following a similar trend. Remainder browner
stalkier sorts tending irregularly lower following quality.
BUYING PATTERN:
Middle East : Active
CIS:  Good Support
Courtesy - J Thomas & Company Private Limited
COONOOR AUCTION
SALE OF - SALE OF- 29TH NOVEMBER 2024 (SALE NO.48)
CTC LEAF
DEMAND:
Good but selective demand.
MARKET:
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was
73.89% (1,519,855.33kgs)
of the total offering of
2,056,779.60Kgs.
Modest volume of best teas were on offer and teas appreciated in value substantially following quality and competition, fanning grades were not on offer. Good category teas also gained dearer prices following quality, except for medium broken at the lower end which saw a slight decline of up to Rs 3. However, the fanning grade offer was bare minimum in this category. Better medium larger & medium broken sold at irregular levels with few top end invoices fetching dearer prices on competition. All the other sorts sold easier by Rs 3 to 5. Fanning sold at steady levels. Medium category teas sold barely steady to easier however, few smaller broken at the top end fetched prices equivalent or more to the better medium categories. The medium broken (especially BOP) and fanning grades found less takers and faced withdrawals. Plainer category teas sold at barely steady on few invoices but generally declined by Rs 3 to 5 with BOP and Fanning grades remaining unsold in large percentage.
BUYING PATTERN:
The major blenders absorbed
00.00%
of the total CTC leaf sold. Regional packateers were active on the best & good teas but selective on the remainders. Up country buyers and local traders were fairly active. Exporters were selective on their purchases
.
ORTHODOX
LEAF
DEMAND:
Good demand continues to persist especially on the well made, cleaner teas.
MARKET:
The whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer with more handsome gains on the blacker well made teas. Broken grades too met with similar trend. Fanning sold at fully firm to occasionally dearer.
BUYING
PATTERN:
Exporters were fairly active on all sorts. Internal traders were selective on their buying on broken and fanning .
CTC DUST
DEMAND:
Good General Demand.
MARKET:
CTC dust offer this week was at
472,384.36Kgs
of which
396,534.84kgs
were sold
(83.94%)
. Small volume of the best category dust on offer sold well and handsome gains were witnessed on select improved invoices. Good category bolder dust sold firm to dearer whilst the finer dust appreciated by Rs 4 to 7 on competition. Better medium dust sold at barely steady prices. Medium and plainer teas sold barely steady to easier by up to Rs 3 to 5.
BUYING PATTERN:
Major blenders were selective whilst the local and regional packateers were active especially on best, good and select better medium dust. The up-country buyers were selective. Exporters were rather selective this week on the medium and plainer teas especially on the blacker sorts at barely steady to easier prices.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND:
Good demand.
MARKET:
High grown primary dust at the lower end was barely steady to easier but well made leafier dust appreciated on competition. Secondary dust sold at steady prices, however powder types were discounted.
BUYING
PATTERN:
Internal & regional packateers were active on primary dust. Exporters were selective on the secondary dust.
Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co.Pvt. Ltd.
